Risk Management Plant (RMP) Executive Summary  5-year resubmission
MGC Pure Chemical America, Inc (MGC) is required to develop a RMP for the Anhydrous Ammonia Plat located in Mesa, Arizona hereafter referred to as the Ammonia process.
As required by 40 CFR 68.155, MGC developed this RMP Executive Summary for the Ammonia process.

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Release Policies
MGCs policy is to respond to emergencies and minimize employee exposure and potential injury. This is done through training of onsite personnel and contractors working on the site, the use of various safeguards to control hazards associated with potentially hazardous work, and the use of alarms during operations to detect anomalies in process operations.
2.	Facility and Regulated Substances
MGC has one regulated substance Anhydrous Ammonia at the Mesa facility. The facility uses anhydrous ammonia and ammonium hydroxide to create ultra-pure ammonium hydroxide. The facility is subject to the Program Level 3 RMP requirements. [The OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation also applies to the facility because the anhydrous ammonia onsite exceeds the PSM limit of 10,000 pounds.]
The following sections briefly describe the elements of the MGC release prevention program that are in place at its stationary source. 

3.	Release Prevention Program at Mesa Plant 
a.	Process Safety Information (PSI)
MGC maintains a PSI record that describes chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with the regulated substance and Covered Process.
b.	Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios
Information on the worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios is maintained in Section 5 of the facility RMP manual  Off-Site Consequence Analysis.

c.	Process Hazardous Analysis (PHA)
MGC conducted PHA studies to identify hazards associated with its Covered Process and review if appropriate controls were in place. The methodology used to carry out these analyses was

What If. Studies undertaken by teams of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations. The PHAs were revalidated at least every five years. Findings and recommendations related to the PHAs were addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA for the Covered Process was completed in April 2023. 
d. Operating Procedures
MGC maintains written operating procedures to safely conduct activities in the Covered Process. These procedures address various modes of operation, such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in these processes.
e.	Training 
MPCA has a training program for employees tasked with operational processes and procedures. Refresher training is provided at least once every three years. MGC maintains records of the training that has been provided to employees.
f.	Mechanical Integrity
MGC has a preventive maintenance program for the equipment in the Covered Process. MGC carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Covered Process equipment examined by these checks includes, among others: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.  
Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. MGC has established and implemented written procedures to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment. Equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 
g.	Management Of Change (MOC)
MGC has a written MOC process for the Covered Process to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or other employees whose tasks are affected by a modificati

on in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to address the modifications. 
h.	Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
MGC has a PSSR program for the Covered Process. The facility performs Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications of the Covered Process. The reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation. A completed PSSR is required prior to introducing hazardous materials to the process.
i.	Compliance Audits
MGC conducts RMP compliance audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP regulation are being implemented. The last compliance audit for the facility was completed in April 2021.
j.	Incident Investigation
MGC investigates incidents that have resulted in, or could reasonably result, in a catastrophic release of ammonia. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situations leading to each incident, as well as corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. Incident Investigation reports related to the Covered Process are retained for a minimum of five years. 
k.	Employee Participation 
MGC has developed a written employee participation plan. MGC employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend measures for improvement.  
l.	Contractors 
Prior to selecting a contractor, MPCA completes an evaluation of the safety performance of the contractor. MGC trains contract employees on potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the Covered Process. Contractors are also informed of the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of ammonia. 

4.	Five-year Accident History
There have been no accidents or releases of the covered chemical within the 5-year tracking period that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite

deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
5.	Emergency Response Program

MGC complies with applicable federal, state, and local regulations related to emergency response plans. This facility has an emergency action plan that provides instructions to employees on how to respond to various emergencies, including releases from the Covered Process. Employees and contractors are also informed of hazards in the workplace. Employees who work with potentially hazardous substances receive training that includes emergency procedures.
MGC coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) so that the LEPC is aware of the Ammonia process and regulated substance and the emergency procedures proposed in the MGC Emergency Action Plan. MGC has provided a copy of the Emergency Response Plan to the following local agencies: 
	City of Mesa Fire Dept. Headquarters
	City of Mesa Police Dept
	Mountain Vista Hospital. 

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The following change is currently being implemented to improve the safety of the ammonia system:
	Recent MOC was written to install additional safety devices on the raw material ammonia tank [AV-5 (hydrostats)].
